narrative:
On October 16th 2023, a shipment of ruffs (Calidris pugnax) were scheduled to travel on flights AA1310 and AA2423
(AWB# 00172012076) from John F Kennedy International (Queens, New York) to Dallas/Fort Worth International Airport
(Texas).
The birds were improperly stacked in transit before the flight took off. Smaller crates containing the ruffs were stacked
underneath larger crates, resulting in one crate containing 10 ruffs to tip over within a luggage transporter. The crate's lid
opened and the 10 ruffs were loose within the transporter. When an American Airlines representative opened the luggage
transporter 2 ruffs escaped. The other 8 ruffs were retrieved and reached their final destination.
A primary enclosure containing a live bird must not be tossed, dropped, or tilted, and must not be stacked in a manner
which may reasonably be expected to result in its falling. The stacking in this case resulted in 2 non-recovered ruffs.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with airline and animal facility representatives.
n

desc: HANDLING.
narrative:
At the time of this inspection, June 20, 2017 at approximately 10:30 am at the American Priority Parcel center at
Dallas/Ft Worth International Airport, two employees were trying to determine why 2 cats had been left in their
covered outdoor area that morning by American Eagle/Envoy Air. Apparently these cats had arrived on American
Airlines flight 387 from Honolulu at 6:20 am that morning. They were scheduled to connect with an American Eagle
flight chartered by Envoy Air for El Paso, TX. It appears the flight going to El Paso had problems with the cargo
area and could not take animals. Instead of keeping the cats at Envoy and rescheduling them as soon as possible
as per their SOP’s they took the animals to Priority Parcel and left them with no explanation.
Any entity subject to the Animal Welfare regulations who transports animals must do so as quickly and efficiently as
possible. Taking animals to another carrier that has no way of tracking the animals in their computer system and
leaving them with no explanation is not transporting animals quickly and efficiently.
Envoy Air needs to ensure their SOP’s for transporting animals are being followed. If the animals need to go to
another facility for temperature or other reasons that should be communicated to the other carrier prior to delivery of
the animals.
To be corrected by: June 30, 2017
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.

desc: PRIMARY ENCLOSURES USED TO TRANSPORT LIVE DOGS AND CATS.
narrative:
An 8 month old labrador retriever was accepted for transport without the words "Live Animals" marked on top of the
primary enclosure (see air waybill # 001PHL77761003). Primary enclosures must be clearly marked on top and on
one or more sides with the words ``Live Animals,'' in letters at least 1 inch (2.5 cm.) high, and with arrows or other
markings to indicate the correct upright position of the primary enclosure. Carriers and intermediate handlers must
not tranport any dog or cat in commerce unless the primary enclosure is clearly marked on top with the words "Live
Animals" in letters at least 1 inch in height.

desc: FOOD AND WATER REQUIREMENTS.
narrative:
There were no food and water receptacles attached inside the primary enclosures for an 8 month old labrador
retriever (see air waybill # 001PHL 77761003). There was no safe way for the carrier or intermediate handler to
offer water or place food without receptacles being attached inside the front door of the enclosure. Food and water
receptacles must be securely attached inside the primary enclosure and placed so that the receptacles can be filled
from outside the enclosure without opening the door.
An exit briefing was conducted with the supervisor/manager.

desc: PRIMARY CONVEYANCES (MOTOR VEHICLE, RAIL, AIR, AND MARINE).
narrative:
While inspecting the travel trailer that is used for the primates it was noted that the side door was in need of
attention.
The wood veneer had begun to peel away from the wood base. This trailer will not be used until June 2016.
However, to ensure that this trailer can be properly cleaned and that the door is structurally sound, this will need to
be repaired.
***To Be Corrected By: May 30, 2016 or before the trailer is used to transport animals.

desc: PRIMARY CONVEYANCES (MOTOR VEHICLE, RAIL, AIR, AND MARINE).
narrative:
While inspecting the Kangaroo's travel trailer it was noted that there are holes in the ceiling panels.
The ceiling vents also have broken screens and / or clasps. This trailer will not be used until June 2016.
However, these areas will need to be repaired to ensure the integrity of the trailer.
***To Be Corrected By: May 30, 2016 or before used to travel to events - whichever comes first
An exit briefing was conducted with the licensee.

desc: FACILITIES, OUTDOOR.
narrative:
The transport trailer that houses the steer is not large enough to turn about freely and to make normal postural
adjustments. I observed the steers back side and nose have contact with the metal enclosure. The steers horns
also had contact with the enclosure numerous times while he was standing still. Continuous contact with the steers
body parts may cause skin problems or possible injury due to his horns getting caught in the opening of the
enclosure. This steer needs to be able to travel comfortably, without having contact with this enclosure.
TO BE CORRECTED BY: FEBRUARY 20, 2014.
Exit interview conducted with the licensee in Charlotte County, Florida.

desc: PRIMARY ENCLOSURES USED TO TRANSPORT LIVE ANIMALS.
narrative:
The enclosure that houses the steer in the transport trailer is not large enough for animal to turn around freely and
to make normal postural adjustments. I observed the steers back side and nose have contact with the metal
enclosure. The steers horns also had contact with the enclosure numerous times while he was standing still.
Continuous contact with the steers body parts may cause skin problems or possible injury due to his horns getting
caught in the opening of the enclosure. This steer needs to be able to travel comfortably, without having contact
with this enclosure.
TO BE CORRECTED BY: FEBRUARY 15, 2014.
Exit interview conducted with the licensee in Charlotte County, Florida.
END OF REPORT.

desc: ACCESS AND INSPECTION OF RECORDS AND PROPERTY; SUBMISSION OF ITINERARIES.
narrative:
A responsible adult was not available to accompany APHIS Officials during the inspection process at 1:00 P.M. on
27-MAR-18.
A telephone call was made to the licensee upon arrival at the Jacksonville fair. The licensee was off property and
would not return for several hours.
My mutual agreement, this inspection report will be E mailed.
As discussed during our telephone conversation, a copy of the itinerary form is attached to this inspection report for
your convenience to use anytime you are in travel status with your animals, This report shall be completed fully and
submitted to the Raleigh Office as per regulation 2.126 (c).

desc: ACCESS AND INSPECTION OF RECORDS AND PROPERTY; SUBMISSION OF ITINERARIES.
narrative:
A responsible adult was not available to accompany APHIS Officials during the inspection process at 13:00hrs on
20-JUN-18.***On Wednesday, June 20th 2018, between 13:00hrs and 13:30hrs, a responsible person was not
available to conduct an inspection. Inspector attempted to contact licensee by (calling cell/home and leaving
message, knocking on door, honking while in driveway). This is the first attempted inspection.
The licensee failed to have a responsible person available to conduct an animal welfare inspection. The facility was
not able to be inspected for compliance with the Animal Welfare Act, regulations and standards to ensure the health
and well-being of the animals. A responsible person must be available to accompany the inspector on an animal
welfare inspection.
Correct from this day forward.”
(Contacted licensee by phone at the airport and he said he was 2 hours away).

desc: FACILITIES, GENERAL.
narrative:
The facility reported that on June 25, 2019, the carcass of the facility’s juvenile North American Porcupine was
discovered in the enclosure of a Red-Tailed Hawk that was adjacent to where the porcupine was housed with it’s
dam. Both the porcupines and the Red-Tailed Hawk were housed in chain-link enclosures while the shared wall
between the two enclosures was modified with wire, vinyl slats, and corrugated plastic so as to prevent contact
between the porcupines and the hawk. Additionally, there are vinyl slats on the wall of the enclosure facing the
aisle in front of the two enclosures and, for management purposes, the Red-Tailed Hawk is tethered within it’s own
enclosure.
The carcass was heavily predated upon when found during the facility’s morning checks and while there were no
open gates to either enclosure and the shared wall was in good repair, it was determined at necropsy that the width
of the head and chest of the porcupine were 38mm and 52mm, respectively. Further inspection of the enclosures
revealed that the gaps between the gates and the door jambs were approximately 50mm of both of the enclosures.
The most likely scenario is that the juvenile porcupine, already identified by the facility as smaller than previous
juvenile porcupines housed in this enclosure, was able to exit the enclosure in the gap of the door jamb, travel down
the aisle, and then enter the enclosure of the adjacent Red-Tailed Hawk through a similar-sized door jamb, where it
was then attacked by the hawk.
In response to the incident, the facility reviewed all enclosures and identified no other animals or enclosures that
presented a similar risk in which an animal would be able to escape through a door jamb. Also, any change in
inhabitants of the enclosures will result in a similar review of animal size and door jamb width to ensure that new
animals introduced will also not be able to escape. Modified chain-link enclosures will no longer be used to house
pregnant porcupines. Instead, they and their young will be housed in enclosures with a maximum wire and door
gap width of 1in (25.4mm).
All indoor and outdoor facilities need to be structurally sound, maintained in good repair, and be constructed in such
a manner as to contain the animals. Failure to do so can result in injury or death to the animal.
Correct by continuing to ensure that all animals are housed in enclosures which are properly maintained and will
prevent escape of the animal. Corrected by the time of inspection.

desc: FACILITIES, OUTDOOR.
narrative:
There is a perimeter fence that surrounds just the lion and tiger enclosures. There are several sections of this fence
where the ground has eroded away and created a gap. There is no support bar or wire along the bottom edge of
the fence.
The areas of erosion combined with the lack of bottom support for the fence has reduced the structural integrity of
the fence and could allow persons or animals to travel underneath it.
The perimeter fence shall be in good repair, and constructed and maintained so that it prevents unauthorized
persons and animals from going through it, and also must function as a secondary containment system for the
animals in the zoo.
Licensee must correct this by replacing the eroded soil along the fences lower edge or by other means that will
minimize the gap and ensure that people or animals can not travel under it.
Correct by: Remains uncorrected

desc: HOUSING FACILITIES, GENERAL.
narrative:
In the travel trailer that houses the dogs’ crates, there is an approximately 1ft by 1ft jagged hole where the AC unit
was torn away. The licensee states the AC unit was removed by the dogs this past weekend. During inspection,
they had free access to the exposed jagged metal edges and were seen poking their heads through the hole.
Licensees must maintain housing facilities so that they are structurally sound, protect the animals from injury and
restrict other animals from entering. The exposed metal edges may cause serious injury to the dogs, and the hole in
the trailer wall allows access to unwanted animals.
Correct by 13 March 2020.

desc: SPACE REQUIREMENTS.
narrative:
During this inspection twelve tigers are kept in pairs in enclosures which measure 4 feet high. Because these
enclosures do not allow for full postural and social adjustments, including stretching upward, these cats must be
allowed out into an exercise area with sufficient height at least once a day for an appropriate period of time,
excluding performance and practice time. During this inspection, the tigers were seen in their enclosures from
10:30 AM through until the 7 PM show time. They were not taken to the building and put in the show ring for
exercise at any time during the day. There is no other exercise pen of any type available to allow the tigers to make
normal postural adjustments. During the last travel inspection on 2-24-17, the tigers were not put into the show ring
for exercise as the trainer was not available long enough to do so. He admitted at that time the tigers do not always
get to exercise daily.
If the cages are not changed or modified to provide sufficient height for the tigers to make normal postural
adjustments including stretching up, then they have to have available daily exercise in an enclosure which provides
this height.
To be corrected by 5-5-17.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with trainer.
Inspection conducted at Spartanburg Memorial Auditorium in Spartanburg, SC.
Additional Inspectors

desc: FACILITIES, GENERAL.
narrative:
(a) Structural strength
There is not an enclosure at the facility that is strong enough to house the tamandua. The animal was discovered
wondering throughout the animal room unsupervised at the start of the inspection. The tamandua was placed into
two different enclosures and escaped from both of enclosures during the time of inspection. The first was a large
veri kennel type travel enclosure. The second was an enclosure constructed from cyclone wire fencing. The
tamandua must not be allowed to wonder through the animal room unsupervised as it could potential injure itself.
Assure that the animal is contained in an appropriate enclosure that is strong enough to contain it.
Note: The animal was placed in a temporary enclosure that appeared to contain it during the time of inspection.
The inspection exit briefing was conducted with the facility owner.

desc: OUTDOOR HOUSING FACILITIES.
narrative:
Shelter from the elements.
The shelter in the far southwest enclosure housing two Australian Shepherds is inadequate. A plastic travel crate is
used for their shelter and does not afford the dogs protection from the wind and rain due to the ventilation openings
in the sides of the crate. There is also not a wind break at the entrance. The roof of the shelter for two Australian
Shepherds in the first enclosure south of the whelping building is in disrepair and does not afford the dogs
protection from rain. The ceiling had water damage and is deteriorated to the point of potentially collapsing.
Inadequate shelter from wind and rain does not ensure that the dogs remain dry able to maintain a comfortable
body temperature. Provide adequate shelter structures for these dogs to ensure their health and comfort. Correct by
16 May 2014.

desc: ACCESS AND INSPECTION OF RECORDS AND PROPERTY; SUBMISSION OF ITINERARIES.
narrative:
The licensee has exhibited animals and stayed overnight in Michigan, Ohio and Wisconsin. The licensee did not
send an itinerary to the office for any of these exhibits.
Any person who is subject to the Animal Welfare regulations and who intends to exhibit any animal at any location
other than the person's approved site (including, but not limited to, circuses, traveling educational exhibits, animal
acts, and petting zoos), except for travel that does not extend overnight, shall submit a written itinerary to the AC
Regional Director.
A written itinerary shall be sent to and received by the AC Director no fewer than 2 days in advance of travel and
shall contain complete and accurate information concerning the whereabouts of any animal intended for exhibition
at any location other than the person's approved site. This is to be completed so that an inspection can be
completed on the facility in travel status and so that the inspector does not attempt an inspection of the home facility
when the licensee is no there.
To be corrected from this day forward.
This was a focused inspection at the home site due to the lack of itineraries from 3 separate animal exhibitions.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
Additional Inspectors
Hammel Kurt, Veterinary Medical Officer

desc: ACCESS AND INSPECTION OF RECORDS AND PROPERTY; SUBMISSION OF ITINERARIES.
narrative:
The licensee sent a written itinerary for an exhibit in Imlay City, MI at the Woods-n-Waters Outdoor Weekend. The
licensee did not include the names, if given, the sex and age of each animal.
Any person who is subject to the Animal Welfare regulations and who intends to exhibit any animal at any location
other than the person's approved site (including, but not limited to, circuses, traveling educational exhibits, animal
acts, and petting zoos), except for travel that does not extend overnight, shall submit a written itinerary to the AC
Regional Director. The itinerary shall include the following: the name, identification number or identifying
characteristics, species (common or scientific name), sex and age of each animal.
The name, if given, sex and age must be included in a written itinerary.
To be corrected from this day forward.
This inspection was conducted on October 16, 2019 and exit interview was conducted with the licensee on
November 5, 2019. At the conclusion of the exit interview the licensee refused to sign the inspection report.
Additional Inspectors
Hammel Kurt, Veterinary Medical Officer

desc: Access and inspection of records and property; submission of itineraries.
narrative:
No written program of veterinary care was available for review at the time of inspection. A written program of veterinary
care gives direction for routine and emergency care of the animals, and may be needed during travel and housing at sites
other than the licensee's approved site. The licensee shall ensure availability of the written program of veterinary care
during travel and make it available for review upon inspection.
Correct from this time forward (06/10/22).

desc: Access and inspection of records and property; submission of itineraries.
narrative:
No itinerary was on file for this exhibitor, who has a team of two camels giving rides for the 2022 summer season at York's
Wild Kingdom in Maine. Travel itineraries ensure accountability for animals exhibited under the license, and facilitate
animal welfare inspections while animals are not housed at the home site.. Licensees are required to submit a travel
itinerary to Animal Care a minimum of two days prior to exhibition at a site other than the licensee's approved site.
Correct from this date forward (06/10/22).
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representative at Yorks Wild Kingdom in York, Maine.
End Section

desc: Access and inspection of records and property; submission of itineraries.
narrative:
The licensee did not submit an itinerary for travel to North Carolina for a performance on July 4th, 2022. Submission of
itineraries is required so that animals can be inspected when they are away from their home site. Correct by 9/21/22 by
submitting itineraries at least 48 hours prior to travel to USDA Animal Care. (Itineraries can be emailed to:
animalcare@usda.gov)

desc: Facilities, general.
narrative:
Two storks housed in separate exhibits managed to escape their primary enclosures on September 19th and September
24th. One Abdim stork and one Marabou stork were able to gain flight and fly over their enclosure structures used to
contain the birds within their exhibits. While the facility reports that wing-clipping and additional provisions were in place to
prevent the birds from leaving their enclosures, they later determined that the wings had grown enough to enable flight.
Animals escaping from primary enclosures are more vulnerable to harm and further injury when they are not safely
contained. They also pose a threat to other people and animals if they are not effectively held in their designated
enclosures as needed to complete routine responsibilities. Housing facilities for birds shall be designed and constructed
appropriately for the species of birds housed in them, remain in good repair, and protect the birds from injury.
Corrective actions were already taken by the facility.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representative.
n

desc: Facilities, general.
narrative:
Primary enclosures failed to protect birds from injury.
***On September 25, 2023 a 1-year-old domestic bantam rooster was found not moving in a pool in the “Duckling Pen”.
After extensive medical interventions and treatments, the animal died. According to medical records and conversations
with staff and the Attending Veterinarian and clinical veterinarian, the rooster died as a result of drowning in the pool. Prior
to its death, the animal had been housed for approximately 3 weeks with another chicken in an enclosure adjacent to the
“Duckling Pen”. On the day of its death, the rooster (who was not flight restricted) flew over an approximately 3-foot tall
baby gate into an adjacent enclosure (the “duckling pen”) which contained a pool of water used for ducklings. The pool of
water was square, approximately 4 feet wide by 4 foot long, and the sides of the pool were steep and smooth. The depth
of the pool in the center was approximately 3 feet deep. Facility staff believe that the rooster fell into the pool and couldn't
get out. The facility has since covered the pool so it is no longer accessible to birds in the enclosure.
***Disposition records show that two North American ruddy ducks “disappeared”, and facility staff and the Attending
Veterinarian stated that the animals were lost to predation, most likely racoons. The facility searched for the birds
thoroughly for multiple days, and officially documented the disappearances on October 31st and October 23rd, 2023 in
facility records. The birds had been living in the “Teton Marsh Exhibit”, which contains a pond and natural marshy areas,
and also houses a variety of waterfowl. The back walls of the enclosure are six-foot-tall chain link, and the front of the
enclosure is an elevated public walkway bordered by an approximately 4-foot tall wire and wooden fence. The birds were
flight restricted (pinioned). The facility has a predator control program in place and has undertaken measures to prevent
additional predation near this exhibit.
Birds that are not protected from hazards or predation may suffer from stress, injury, or death.
Correct by ensuring that bird enclosures are maintained in good repair, protect the birds from injury, contain the birds, and
restrict other animals from entering who may negatively affect the welfare of the birds within. Corrected at the time of
inspection.

desc: ACCESS AND INSPECTION OF RECORDS AND PROPERTY; SUBMISSION OF ITINERARIES.
narrative:
The required written itineraries for traveling educational exhibits has never been received by the AC Regional
Director. A facility who is subject to the Animal Welfare regulations and who intends to exhibit any animal at any
location other than the person's approved site, except for travel that does not extend overnight, must submit a
written itinerary to the AC Regional Director. The itinerary shall be received by the AC Regional Director no fewer
than 2 days in advance of any travel and must contain complete and accurate information concerning the
whereabouts of any animal intended for exhibition at any location other than the person's approved site. If an
engagement is accepted for which travel will begin with less than 48 hours notice, the facility must immediately
contact the AC Regional Director in writing with the required information. APHIS expects such situations to occur
infrequently, and facilities who repeatedly provide less than 48 hours notice will, after notice by APHIS, be subject to
increased scrutiny under the Act.
The itinerary shall include the following:
(1) The name of the person who intends to exhibit the animal and transport the animal for exhibition purposes,
including any business name and current Act license or registration number and, in the event that any animal is
borrowed/loaned, the name of the person who owns such animal.
(2) The name, identification number or identifying characteristics, species (common or scientific name), sex and
age of each animal.
(3) The names, dates, and locations (with addresses) where the animals will travel, be housed, and be exhibited,
including all anticipated dates and locations (with addresses) for any stops and layovers that allow or require
removal of the animals from the transport enclosures. Unanticipated delays of such length must be reported to the
AC Regional Director the next APHIS business day.
The facility must submit current written itineraries to the AC Regional Director immediately and then on a regular
basis as engagements are confirmed.
Correct by: June 8, 2017
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with two facility representatives.

desc: ACCESS AND INSPECTION OF RECORDS AND PROPERTY; SUBMISSION OF ITINERARIES.
narrative:
As of January 30, 2015, there were no current itineraries available that indicated that four bears were going to be
exhibited in New Jersey from January 30, 2015 through February 2, 2015. According to the owner, an itinerary was
submitted, via e-mail, to the Regional office in Ft. Collins, CO. However, a check with the Regional office indicated
that no current itinerary was found. The owner also indicated to the APHIS official that this particular show was set
up on short notice.
Accurate itineraries are necessary to allow APHIS officials the ability to inspect the exhibit animals and to ensure
their health and well-being while they are in travel status.
Accurate itineraries must be submitted in an approriate amount of time to ensure that the required information is
made available to APHIS officials, as required.
*Note: For short notice engagements, the exhibitor shall IMMEDIATELY contact the Regional Diretor, in writing,
with the required information.
TO BE CORRECTED BY: FEBRUARY 12, 2015
The exit briefing was conducted with the facility representative via telephone.
This on-the-road inspection was conducted in Lakewood, NJ.

desc: SPACE REQUIREMENTS.
narrative:
While in travel status for several months of the year, the primary enclosure for the three bears is a rectangular cattle
panel enclosure set up in a building on a concrete floor with shavings. There are no visual barriers in the enclosure
that allows the animals to avoid each other or get out of view of the guests. There are no furniture items, water tubs,
straw or bedding that allows the animals to express normal postural or social adjustments. Black bears normally
engage in postural behaviors of swimming, climbing, digging and denning and socially need to be able to have the
choice to get away from each other.
Cindy the female bear was observed pacing along the back panel for an extended period of time before and after
the show. This occurred on Friday and Saturday of the visit and inspection. She was facing the back wall away from
the public side and would seeming only break from the pacing behavior if the younger bear “Barney” would grab at
her legs repeatedly. She would then turn on him mouth open until he would submit and she would begin pacing
again. Pacing in black bears is an abnormal behavior pattern and can indicate stress, frustration or an underlying
medical condition.
Andy the older male bear laid in the center of the enclosure for the majority of the day and when he would get up,
his movements were stiff, slow and seemingly arthritic in nature. There has been no modification to the enclosure
with the addition of straw or bedding that would allow Andy to get off the concrete to be more comfortable and the
concrete can exacerbate his debility. In addition, several times “Barney” the younger bear would try and elicit a
response from the older bear and would get on top of him and Andy would tolerate it for a few moments before
opening his mouth and the younger bear would get off. Andy has no way to separate himself from the younger bear
which can cause additional stress or is potentially painful in his condition.
Barney is the youngest bear with hair loss over several parts of his body including a bald patch on his hindquarters.
Barney is the most active bear and was observed trying to elicit behaviors from the other bears, rolling on his back
and grabbing his back paws and trying to run around. Barney is scratching and rubbing his back on the concrete
which has caused a bald spot on his hindquarters. Barney was observed pacing for short periods of time. He needs
to be provided functional elements in this enclosure to promote normal behaviors as to prevent any abnormal ones
like pacing from becoming a continuous and rigid behavior.
Correct by: March 4, 2017
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
This inspection occurred over a two day period March 24-25, 2017 at the Lewis and Clark County Fairgrounds in
Helena, MT.
Additional Inspectors
Hood Brian, Animal Care Inspector

desc: SPACE REQUIREMENTS.
narrative:
-While in travel status for several months of the year, the primary enclosure for the three bears is a rectangular
cattle panel enclosure set up in a building with pine shavings on the floor. There are no visual barriers in the
enclosure that allow the animals to avoid each other or get out of view of the guests. There are no furniture items,
water tubs, straw or bedding that allow the animals to express normal postural or social adjustments. Black bears
normally engage in postural behaviors of swimming, climbing, digging and denning and socially need to be able to
have the choice to get away from each other.
-Cindy, the female bear, was observed pacing in the travel trailer for at least 10 minutes and was observed pacing
inside the exhibit along the front panel for a period of time. In both the travel trailer and the public exhibit Cindy
seemingly would only break from the pacing behavior if the younger bear Barney would grab at her legs. She would
then turn on him mouth open until he would submit and she would begin pacing again. Pacing in black bears is an
abnormal behavior pattern and can indicate stress, frustration, or an underlying medical condition.
-When Andy, the older male bear, was brought out of the travel trailer and placed in the public exhibit, and when
treats were provided his movements were stiff and slow. Andy has been diagnosed with arthritis by a veterinarian.
Several times Barney, the younger 4 year old black bear, would try and elicit a response from the older bear and
would get on top of him and Andy would tolerate it for a few moments before opening his mouth and the younger
bear would get off. Andy has no way to separate himself from the younger bear which can cause additional stress or
is potentially painful in his geriatric condition.
-This inspection occurred on the MSU campus in Bozeman, MT.
Additional Inspectors
Mckinnie Carolyn, Supervisory Animal Care Specialist

desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
narrative:
A Patagonian Cavy was euthanized due to a fracture leg that was left to heal on its own. Facility representative stated the
injury started as a small injury on the lower leg and after it healed when the animal put weight on it the bone protruded
through. Veterinary care was not provided after bone was seen. Attempts were made to place the cavy in a travel carrier,
but facility was not able to do so and the Attending veterinarian was not contacted. The attending veterinarian came 6
months after the first injury was seen and performed a walkthrough the facility on March 9, 2023. The attending
veterinarian recommended that the facility take the Patagonian Cavy to the local veterinarian hospital for diagnostics and
possible surgery. The cavy was euthanized at the veterinary hospital. The facility also elected to transfer their Patagonian
Cavy population to another licensed facility to better care for their animals. Injuries and any abnormalities seen must be
reported to the Attending veterinarian as soon as they are noticed. Daily observation of all animals and direct and frequent
communication with the attending veterinarian is required so that care can be provided in a timely matter. Corrected at the
time of inspection.

desc: Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being.
narrative:
At time of inspection, the documented avian environment enhancement plan was incomplete and missing the species-
specific environment enhancement section for adult raptors and ravens on hand in the raptor free flight program. These
birds include 1 Eurasian Eagle Owl, 2 Great Horned Owls, 1 Gray Hawk, 1 Ferruginous Hawk, 1 Prairie Falcon, 2
Peregrine Falcons, 10 Harris' Hawks,1 Crested Caracara, 1 Red-tailed Hawk and 2 Chihuahuan Ravens. Failure to
develop and document a species-specific environment enhancement plan for all birds can lead to a decline in
psychological welfare of the animals. A species-specific environment enhancement plan is required to be fully developed,
documented and followed in order to promote the psychological well-being of birds.
Correct by 24 October 2023.

desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
narrative:
The enclosure of an adult Harris' Hawk "Rudy" had excessive accumulation of excreta on the walls, floor and joint
between the walls and floor. Facility representatives reported that deep cleaning of the enclosure occurs on a seasonal
schedule in conjunction with the raptor free flight program which begins in October and continues to April, light cleaning
occurs on a daily basis and disinfection occurs on a weekly basis. Failure to remove excreta as often as necessary to
prevent excessive accumulation of waste may cause the animal to be exposed to disease hazards. Excreta and food
waste must be removed from the primary enclosures and from under and around primary enclosures as often as
necessary to prevent excessive accumulation of feces and food waste, to prevent soiling of birds contained in the primary
enclosures, and to reduce disease hazards, insects, pests, and odors.
Correct by 24 October 2023.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
n

desc: Health certification and identification.
narrative:
In January 2022, the licensee transported a nonhuman primate (Montel the capuchin) from a state authority to their facility
site with the intent of exhibition without a health certificate issued by a licensed veterinarian. Not having required
documentation and assurance for health and fitness of animal to travel may result in their illness or injury. Exhibitors who
transport a nonhuman primate in commerce shall have a health certificate executed and issued by a licensed veterinarian
within 10 days of travel to accompany the animal.
Correct from this date forward of 07 July 2023.

desc: FACILITIES, GENERAL.
narrative:
A big horned sheep (BHS) escaped from her exhibit by jumping over an approximately 7 to 8 foot exhibit wall and
an additional barrier fence surrounding the exhibit. A facility representative stated that the incident occurred while
the animal was out on exhibit with a keeper who was performing routine cleaning of this area. The facility
representative stated that the keeper made attempts to lock out the BHS from the exhibit prior to cleaning, but the
BHS would not go into the back holding area with the 4 other animals for feeding.
Although immediate assistance from zoo personnel, including keepers and the veterinary staff, was utilized, they
were unable to capture the BHS on the premises. The facility representative stated that the BHS made its way over
to a second floor walkway/ balcony that overlooks the perimeter fence, and jumped over it. After leaving the zoo
grounds, the BHS was hit by a car but was able to travel to an adjoining neighborhood where it was darted and
captured by zoo veterinarians and staff members. The animal died shortly after.
Further evaluation of the construction and layout of the exhibit and the walkway/balcony that overlooks the
perimeter fence is needed. According to a facility representative, measures, in addition to those already in place,
are being taken to minimize the risk of animals escaping from this enclosure and over a section of the perimeter
fence.
Animal housing facilities should be structurally sound and maintained in a manner that protects the animals from
injury and to contain the animals.
To be corrected by December 19, 2014
An exit briefing was conducted with a facility representative.

desc: ACCESS AND INSPECTION OF RECORDS AND PROPERTY; SUBMISSION OF ITINERARIES.

desc: ACCESS AND INSPECTION OF RECORDS AND PROPERTY; SUBMISSION OF ITINERARIES.
narrative:
An inspection was attempted at the licensee's home site at 12:30 P.M. on 10/19/2016. An adult (not a
representative of the licensee) at that location stated that the licensee was out of town exhibiting his animals. The
licensee was then contacted by telephone and stated that he was exhibiting his animals in Arizona. At time of this
inspection, no current itinerary has been received by USDA-APHIS-Animal Care that accounts for this travel.
In the case of traveling exhibitors, itineraries must be submitted to USDA via fax, mail, or electronic mail at least two
days prior to any overnight travel. The itinerary should contain complete and accurate information concerning the
whereabouts of any animal intended for exhibition at any location other than the person's approved site.
To be corrected by submission of an itinerary for all future travel in which regulated activities will be conducted.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.

desc: ACCESS AND INSPECTION OF RECORDS AND PROPERTY; SUBMISSION OF ITINERARIES.
narrative:
At the time of inspection, there were 3 cats and 4 dogs in overnight travel status. Although a previous itinerary had
been submitted to AC West for travel, the animals had returned by early July. There was no itinerary for the current
travel.
The itinerary for overnight travel shall be submitted to the regional director no fewer than 2 days in advance of travel
and shall contain complete and accurate information concerning the whereabouts of any animal intended for
exhibition at any location other than the person's approved site.
Under subpart (1) The itinerary shall include the following:
(i) The name of the person who intends to exhibit the animal and transport the animal for exhibition purposes,
including any business name and current Act license or registration number and, in the event that any animal is
leased, borrowed, loaned, or under some similar arrangement, the name of the person who owns such animal;
(ii) The name, identification number or identifying characteristics, species (common or scientific name), sex and age
of each animal; and
(iii) The names, dates, and locations (with addresses) where the animals will travel, be housed, and be exhibited,
including all anticipated dates and locations (with addresses) for any stops and layovers that allow or require
removal of the animals from the transport enclosures. Unanticipated delays of such length shall be reported to the
AC Regional Director the next APHIS business day. APHIS Regional offices are available each weekday, except on
Federal holidays, from 8 a.m. to 5 p.m.
Correct for all future travel.
Inspection conducted by Jeanne Lorang ACI and Dr. Katharine Frank, VMO.
Exit interview conducted with Facility representative.
Additional Inspectors
Lorang Jeanne, Animal Care Inspector

desc: FACILITIES, OUTDOOR.
narrative:
The camels are contained in a back holding pen of about 50' x 100'. These twelve camels do not have any artifical
or natural shade. At the end of the event, the animals had access to the main arena and there was no shade there
either. The camels shall have sufficient shade by natural or artificial means to allow these animals kept outdoors to
protect themselves from direct sunlight. For the well-being and health of the animals, a system is needed to ensure
that adequate shade is provided at each travel location.
************
To be corrected by: September 20,2014 or next event
An exit briefing was conducted with the facility representative

desc: ACCESS AND INSPECTION OF RECORDS AND PROPERTY; SUBMISSION OF ITINERARIES.
narrative:
The licensee did not submit an updated itinerary prior to travel for exhibition. A current itinerary needs to be
submitted so that an inspection can be conducted. The licensee must ensure that a current itinerary is submitted to
USDA-Animal Care no fewer than 2 days in advance of travel or immediately if the exhibitor accepts an
engagement for which travel will begin in less than 48 hours.
To be corrected by March 17, 2020.
The exit interview was conducted with a facility representative.

desc: ACCESS AND INSPECTION OF RECORDS AND PROPERTY; SUBMISSION OF ITINERARIES.
narrative:
A responsible adult was not available to accompany APHIS Officials during the inspection process at 1:35 pm on
12-Mar-20.
No one was present at the home site even though the submitted itinerary stated that they would be at this location.
I called a facility representative who said that the animals were in travel status.

desc: PRIMARY ENCLOSURES.
narrative:
* Approximately one week before the inspection, the licensee brought all the nonhuman primates in from their
outdoor enclosures to a heated barn due to the cold weather. The licensee is near completion of constructing a
second, heated barn since the one does not have enough space to house all the licensee's birds and primates.
Due to space constraints in the barn, the licensee housed one pair of adult ring-tailed lemurs in a medium-sized dog
travel crate and another pair of ring-tailed lemurs (with an infant) in a large dog travel crate. The medium crate was
21 inches tall and provided 2.9 square feet of floor space. The large crate provided 5.1 square feet of floor space
and was 30 inches tall. Adult lemurs are required to be housed in enclosures which are at least 30 inches tall and
provide each adult with at least 3 square feet of floor space. Therefore, the medium crate was too small and too
short for even one ring-tailed lemur. The large crate provided the minimum amount of space required for one lemur,
but did not provide adequate space for the two adults housed in it. Primates require sufficient space to allow them
to make normal postural adjustments for their health and well-being.
** The licensee must ensure that primary enclosures provide each nonhuman primate with the minimum floor space
and height required by the regulations. Specifically, each ring-tailed lemur must have at least 3.0 square feet of
floor space (6.0 square feet if there are two adults) and at least 30 inches of height in their primary enclosures. TO
BE CORRECTED BY: 24 November 2014.

desc: Access and inspection of records and property; submission of itineraries.
narrative:
The licensee has not submitted a written itinerary to the Deputy Administrator notifying us of their overnight travels. Not
submitting an itinerary makes it difficult for USDA inspectors to know when and where the licensee's animals will be. It
doesn't allow for APHIS officials to ensure animal welfare is being addressed by the licensee. The licensee must submit
an itinerary to the Deputy Administrator no fewer than 2 days in advance of any travel or they must contact the Deputy
Administrator immediately if the licensee accepts an engagement for which travel will begin with less than 48 hours'
notice. Correct by 7/30/22.

desc: ACCESS AND INSPECTION OF RECORDS AND PROPERTY; SUBMISSION OF ITINERARIES.
narrative:
Section 2.126(b) - Access and inspection of records and property: A responsible adult shall be made available to
accompany APHIS officials during the inspection process.
A responsible adult was not available to accompany APHIS Officials during the inspection process at
10:05am-10:50am on 08/25/2015.
Dr. Digesualdo and I arrived at Mr. Terranovas home facility at 10:05 am. The gates were closed and had a chain
around them. At 10:11am I called the cell phone of Mr. Terranova, he did not answer so I left a message stating we
were at the facility to conduct an inspection and would he return my call and I left my cell phone number on his
voice mail.
At 10:20am after receiving no phone call I sent a text to Mr. Terranova on his cell phone number and stated again
that we were at the facility to conduct an inspection and that his last itinerary received by the western regional office
of Animal Care showed no further exhibiting or travel after the 17th of August so that he and the animals should
have been back at the home facility or an updated itinerary should have been submitted to the western regional
office of Animal Care showing the changes to the itinerary and the time periods it covered.
Mr. Terranova I request you contact me by email or cell phone to let me know when you or your designated person
for inspection will be at the home facility and available for inspection.
Email address: donnovan.l.fox@aphis.usda.gov
Cell phone number: 903-570-1518
I also request that if you have not done so prior to receipt of this inspection report you send a current itinerary to the
western regional office of Animal Care with current information.
END OF REPORT.

desc: ACCESS AND INSPECTION OF RECORDS AND PROPERTY; SUBMISSION OF ITINERARIES.
narrative:
At the time of this inspection a group of animals that included 5 tigers, were off site at a traveling location. The
animals had been housed overnight at this location for at least 5 days. As of the date of this inspection no itinerary
regarding the overnight travel and off site exhibition had been filed with the regional office. The last itinerary
received by the regional office indicated all animals would be at the home site after September 2015.
Itineraries must be received by the AC regional director no fewer than 2 days in advance of any travel and shall
contain complete and accurate information concerning the whereabouts of any animal intended for overnight
exhibition at any location other than the licensee's approved site.
The inspection and exit interview were conducted with Drs. M. Moore, E. Pannilll and the facility representative
designated by the licensee.
Additional Inspectors
Pannill Elizabeth, Veterinary Medical Officer

desc: ACCESS AND INSPECTION OF RECORDS AND PROPERTY; SUBMISSION OF ITINERARIES.
narrative:

Any person who exhibits any animal at any location other than the person's approved site shall submit a written

To be corrected within two days of receiving this report.

desc: Contingency planning.
narrative:
At the time of the inspection, the licensee did not have a contingency plan. Traveling entities such as this one must carry

The licensee was unaware that a contingency plan was needed. The inspector provided the licensee with the contingency

appropriate plan to provide for the care and transport of their animals in the event of an emergency or disaster.
CORRECT BY: 4/10/23.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representative.

This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representative.

desc: PRIMARY ENCLOSURES USED TO TRANSPORT LIVE ANIMALS.
narrative:
On February 25, 2016 the licensee presented and left for air transportation four young sugar gliders housed in four
individual primary enclosures. The four enclosures had tape applied to the exterior that sealed all ventilation
openings on the enclosures. Removal of the externally applied tape on one enclosure revealed the openings had
also been sealed with a layer of tape applied to the inside of the enclosure.
No dealer shall offer for transportation any live animal in a primary enclosure that does not conform to the following
ventilation requirement: when there are ventilation openings located on all four walls of the primary enclosure the
ventilation openings on each wall shall be at least 8 percent of the total surface area of each wall.
By sealing the openings on all four sides of the enclosures the animals were essentially provided with no openings
for ventilation. Insufficient ventilation during transportation will compromise animal well being by restricting oxygen
and could result in death of the animal. Animals must not be accepted for transportation when housed in primary
enclosures that do not meet requirements for adequate ventilation under the Animal Welfare Act.
Correct by: Immediate.
The inspection was conducted with United Airlines representatives. The exit interview was conducted on February
25, 2016 with the licensee via telephone.

desc: CLEANING, SANITIZATION, HOUSEKEEPING, AND PEST CONTROL.
narrative:
Food preparation room/kitchen: There was an excessive buildup of dust, dirt and debris on the floor as well as
underneath and inside cabinet shelves/drawers used to store animal items.
Travel vehicle: A moderate accumulation of dust, hair, and debris is present in animal areas including: the floor, in
corners, on the air vents, and between spaces of stacked dog crates.
Premises where housing facilities are located must be kept clean, free of clutter and in good repair in order to
protect the health and well-being of the animals, to prevent the harborage of vermin and pests, and to facilitate the
prescribed husbandry practices. A system of maintaining effective housekeeping practices must be in place.
Correct by 12/14/2015
Exit interview conducted with facility representative.

desc: ACCESS AND INSPECTION OF RECORDS AND PROPERTY; SUBMISSION OF ITINERARIES.
narrative:
Any person who intends to exhibit any animal at any location other than the person's approved site and stay
overnight must submit a written itinerary received by the AC Regional Director no fewer than 2 days in advance of
any travel and shall contain complete and accurate information concerning the whereabouts of any animal intended
for exhibition at any location. The itinerary shall include the exact address, dates, number of animals, name of the
person exhibiting and transporting the animal, etc.
No itinerary for the current travel to the Pet Expo at Orange County Fair has been submitted to the regional office.
Correct for all future travel.

desc: ACCESS AND INSPECTION OF RECORDS AND PROPERTY; SUBMISSION OF ITINERARIES.

To be corrected by submission of an itinerary for all future travel in which regulated activities will be conducted.

desc: Access and inspection of records and property; submission of itineraries.

n

desc: ATTENDING VETERINARIAN AND ADEQUATE VETERINARY CARE (DEALERS AND EXHIBITORS).
narrative:
The owner is not observing the animals to assess their health and well-being on a daily basis. This is especially
evident because of the health issues (matted fur and severely overgrown claws) that three of the cats are
experiencing. The dog Babaii should have been seen for his eyes as soon as any abnormality was noticed. To be
corrected from this day on.
Exit briefing conducted with licensee.
Inspection conducted at travel location in Conway, SC.
Additional Inspectors
Binkley F, Veterinary Medical Officer

desc: FACILITIES, GENERAL.
narrative:
** The lioness "(cid:28)Matilda"(cid:29) had a door in to her enclosure that consisted of chain link wire attached to a metal tubular
door frame by metal fasteners. At the bottom of gate the fasteners had become unattached allowing the wire to be
pushed away from the door frame. The door was not maintained in good repair to protect the animals from injury or
to contain the animals.
** The cougar "(cid:28)Sabrina(cid:29)" had a piece of metal sticking out 2-3 inches off a post inside the enclosure at a level that
could cause a laceration. There were also two hinge lag screws sticking out of a post in a doorway from one part of
the frame to another part. These lag screws could cause a laceration. There was a doorway from her enclosure to
the adjacent enclosure that was open. It had two 2 x 6 boards vertically at the bottom of the opening about 3 inches
apart that the cougar could put its foot down in when traveling across the threshold. There were sharp points from a
chain link fence inside the gap that could cause an injury.
** In the night house of a black bear there was a piece of sheet metal that was jagged and extending into the night
house that could cause an injury. Also roofing of the enclosure toward the right end of the pen had debris on top
and was falling down. The top of the fencing for the ceiling is bowing which could eventually cave in.
** In the enclosure of 4 grizzly bears there was a piece of wire paneling that had been cut with pointed pieces of
about 3-4 inches extending into the doorway where they would travel from one section of the enclosure to another.
** In the enclosure for the goats, sheep and pigs there was a rubber strip and several strands of the hay bale twine
lying on the ground. These pieces should be removed to prevent ingestion.
Failure to maintain housing facilities in a structurally sound manner can cause injury to the animals. The affected
structures must be repaired or replaced and all housing facilities should be maintained and kept structurally sound
to protect and contain the animals.

desc: INFORMATION AS TO BUSINESS; FURNISHING OF SAME BY DEALERS, EXHIBITORS, OPERATORS OF AUCTION SALES, INTERMEDIATE HANDLERS, AND CARRIERS.
narrative:
The caretaker of the property informed this inspector that the licensee has not returned home from his 2014 tour.
The last itinerary sent indicated that the licensee would be in travel status until November 18, 2014.
You must keep your itinerary current, and shall inform the Raleigh Regional Office of your route/itinerary when you
are away from your home base for 4 or more consecutive days.
Correct immediately upon receipt of this inspection report.

desc: ATTENDING VETERINARIAN AND ADEQUATE VETERINARY CARE (DEALERS AND EXHIBITORS).
narrative:
Two of the 8 random dogs that were inspected (Wendy & Trivis) has accumulations of hard tarter encasing some of
the pre molars/molars making it difficult to visualize the normal shape of the entire tooth.
These large amounts of tartar can (and do) progress to gum disease, bad breath, heart problems, kidney disease,
pain in the gums/mouth, and difficulty in eating & chewing if left untreated.
The licensee is currently offering all of the dogs dental chews in an effort to control the tarter buildups, but this does
not appear to be entirely effective for, at least, these two dogs.
There were also 2 unopened boxes of Heartguard Blue that expired in April 1015. The licensee has other
medications for the prevention of heartworms, and these two boxes were disposed of immediately.
Not removing the build up of large amounts of tarter on teeth, and using expired medications are not appropriate
methods to control, prevent, and treat diseases.
Have your veterinarian examine all of your dogs teeth and gums and treat accordingly.
Correct by January 15, 2016
The exit interview was conducted with the licensee.
When your 2016 travel route is known, please write the Raleigh Regional Office and provide your dates of travel,
locations, & number of animals on an itinerary.

narrative:

A responsible adult was not available to accompany APHIS Officials during the inspection process at 11:15 AM on
10/17/2014.
The licensee was in travel status out of Florida. Animal Care has no current itinerary on file. An itinerary is required

desc: ACCESS AND INSPECTION OF RECORDS AND PROPERTY; SUBMISSION OF ITINERARIES.
narrative:
***A written itinerary was either not submitted to the APHIS Regional Office that did not include dates and locations
of exhibition in Honolulu, Hawaii or was not received within the 48 hours prior to travel. The itinerary shall be
received by the AC Regional Director no fewer than 2 days in advance of any travel and shall contain complete and
accurate information concerning the whereabouts of any animal intended for exhibition at any location other than
the person's approved site.
To be corrected from this date forward.
Inspection and exit interview conducted with facility representative.

desc: EMPLOYEES OR ATTENDANTS.
narrative:
Five sea lions are under the care of two caretakers in a travel exhibit. The head keeper has worked with this
company for two years. Due to multiple items cited and noted during this inspection, this keeper does not appear to
have adequate training and knowledge to be the primary caretaker for these animals. Items seen include: serious
eye conditions are not recognized and reported; not recognizing the importance of shade in exhibiting marine
mammals; medical records are incomplete not indicating which eyes are treated when treated; pH monitoring is not
adequate; water treatments are added without using measured amounts and are not documented; and animals are
not released into bigger pools in timely manner. The caretaker does not have a copy of the USDA regulations and
has not read them. Old and newer bite slash wounds were observed on both arms and she stated Poonky will play
attack. During the inspection, the two oldest sea lions went off the stage and onto the grass by the public barrier.
The secondary caretaker needed the primary caretakers help to return them to the stage. All of these items show
the current caretakers have not been adequately trained and supervised to maintain the professionally acceptable
level of husbandry practices required by USDA. These employees need to receive additional training and
supervision. To be corrected by 6-3-16.

desc: VETERINARY CARE.
narrative:
The medical records for the 5 sea lions do not show the attending veterinarian visually examined the sea lions at
least semi-annually. There were only reports for an annual physical examination at the first of the years in 2015 and
2016. If these animals were seen by the veterinarian, it needs to be documented. Since several of these sea lions
are exhibiting painful eye conditions, the veterinarian should be regularly consulted about these conditions. This
does not appear to be done. To be corrected by 6-1-16.
This is a partial report of an inspection conducted at the travel location at Heritage Park in Simpsonville, SC.
Inspection of sea lions Kitty, Stella, Zoey, Poonky, and Lilly. Exit briefing conducted with owner by phone.

desc: ATTENDING VETERINARIAN AND ADEQUATE VETERINARY CARE (DEALERS AND EXHIBITORS).
narrative:
At the start of this inspection all 5 sea lions were in the smaller pool. Several were squinting or keeping an eye
closed. These are signs of obvious discomfort and painful eye conditions. The 14 year old South American Sea
Lion Kitty has a cloudy right eye. Her veterinary exam done on 2-1-16 did not indicate any eye issues and stated
she was fluorescein negative. During the photo shoots Kitty was seen squinting her eyes as at 5:30 pm the three
sea lions being used for photos were looking directly into the setting sun due to the orientation of the trailer set up.
Sea lions, especially those with eye issues, should never be made to look directly into the sun.
During most of this inspection, Zoey (13 year old California sea lion) was holding her right eye closed. There is no
record of any veterinary consultation or initiation of medical treatment. The pH of the outdoor pool at the time of
inspection was 7 but may have been much lower as the testing method only goes as low as 7. The sea lions had
not been placed in this pool yet. The caretaker added soda to bring the pH up, but varying pHs of the water can be
affecting the eyes.
A medical record dated 6-26-15 stated Zoey had her eye tightly closed (record does not state which eye). There is
no notation of a veterinary consultation, but Muro drops (hypertonic saline) was given 3 times daily for several days
along with oral 500 mg amoxicillin. The record states the cloudiness left. Two months later the medical record
shows the closed eye happened again but does not state which eye, and does not state if the veterinarian was
consulted. This animal is having recurrent, chronic eye probles which are not being adequately addressed and
treated properly.
Lilly, a talkative 3 year old California sea lion, was holding her left eye closed or squinting during much of this
inspection. The veterinary exam of Lilly on 2-1-16 indicated corneal opacities on both eyes.
There is gentamicin ophthalmic drops in the medical cabinet and the caretaker stated it is used on Zoey when her
eyes are cloudy. There is no script on the bottle or in the medical records as to when to use this.
The veterinarian prescribed all the sea lions have easy access to salt water. This is not being done as the level
today is zero. The veterinarian also found titers for Leptospirosis on Zoey and Kitty and recommended further
testing to see if any active infection was occurring or if it was vaccine related. There is no indication the follow up
diagnostics were done.
All of these sea lions need to have a thorough eye evaluation by a veterinarian to treat for any lesions and specific
protocols need to be in place for medical treatments of eyes. This traveling exhibit has a bright blue pool with no
shade, no shade on the stage and the stage was set up to face the sun at this location. Changes in their
environment need to be made to correct any eye irritations and to prevent further eye diseases.
To be corrected by 5-22-16.
This is a partial report of an inspection of a direct non-compliant item found at the travel location at Heritage Park in
Simpsonville, SC. Inspection of sea lions Kitty, Stella, Zoey, Poonky, and Lilly.
Exit briefing conducted with trainer.

desc: ATTENDING VETERINARIAN AND ADEQUATE VETERINARY CARE (DEALERS AND EXHIBITORS).
narrative:
Upon observation one female sea lion maintained closure of its right eye in and out of the pool. The manager
claims this animal had a whisker from one of the other sea lions touch her eye two days ago and began closing it at
that time. The manager has not contacted a veterinarian and has been giving this animal aspirin to control any pain
its in. The closed eye behavior could be a sign of discomfort. It is up to the manager who is responsible for these
animals while in transport to maintain direct and frequent communication with the attending veterinarian with any
injury that occurs, so that adequate veterinary treatment is given in a timely manner for the health of the animals.
To Be Corrected by June 30, 2017.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative on June 29, 2017 at the travel
location of Brockton Fair, MA.
Additional Inspectors
Hadjis Tonya, Supervisory Animal Care Specialist

desc: HEALTH CERTIFICATION AND IDENTIFICATION.
narrative:
* The recorded inspection date by a licensed veterinarian on two health certificates has exceeded the 10 day time
limit for those inspected animals to be shipped. Thirteen puppies inspected on July 3, 2014 by a licensed
veterinarian were shipped on July 21, 2014. Seven puppies inspected on August 7, 2014 by a licensed veterinarian
were shipped on August 25, 2014. Health certificates provide information on the health status of all animals being
shipped within the 10 day time limit. The health status could change affecting the travel status if the shipment date
exceeds 10 days past recorded date on the health certificate. The licensee must ensure that all animals are
shipped within 10 days of the recorded date of inspection by a licensed veterinarian on the health certificate. To be
corrected from this date forward.
* The facility inspection and verbal exit briefing done on 12/2/14 were conducted with the licensee and Robert
Bacon ACI.
* Copy of the inspection report was sent by certified and regular mail.

desc: ACCESS AND INSPECTION OF RECORDS AND PROPERTY; SUBMISSION OF ITINERARIES.
narrative:
In accordance with 2.126(c) a written itinerary is required to be submitted to the Regional Director no fewer than 2
days in advance of any travel and shall contain complete and accurate information concerning the whereabouts of
any animal intended for exhibition at any location other than the person's approved site. As defined in the
regulation, the itinerary shall include the following:
(i) The name of the person who intends to exhibit the animal and transport the animal for exhibition purposes,
including any business name and current Act license or registration number and, in the event that any animal is
leased, borrowed, loaned, or under some similar arrangement, the name of the person who owns such animal;
(ii) The name, identification number or identifying characteristics, species (common or scientific name), sex and age
of each animal; and
(iii) The names, dates, and locations (with addresses) where the animals will travel, be housed, and be exhibited,
including all anticipated dates and locations (with addresses) for any stops and layovers that allow or require
removal of the animals from the transport enclosures. Unanticipated delays of such length shall be reported to the
AC Regional Director the next APHIS business day. APHIS Regional offices are available each weekday, except on
Federal holidays, from 8 a.m. to 5 p.m.
As a Class C exhibitor without a primary site, submitting an itinerary for the traveling animals is crucial to ensuring
that the animals are maintained in accordance with the Animal Welfare Act. An internet search documented
evidence of Rockets K9 Comets performing at the Santa Cruz County Fair on September 19th, 2015 and press
coverage by KXNews in Minot, North Dakota of Rockets K9 Comets performing at the North Dakota State Fair in
late July, 2015. The KXNews coverage included video of Ashley Hoskins, one of the licensees. There have been
no itineraries submitted to the Regional Director or AC West this year.
Itineraries must be submitted to the Regional Director with the required information no fewer than 2 days in advance
of any travel. Exhibitors who repeatedly provide less than 48 hours(cid:25) notice will be subjected to increased scrutiny
under the Act.
To be Corrected from this day forward.

desc: ACCESS AND INSPECTION OF RECORDS AND PROPERTY; SUBMISSION OF ITINERARIES.
narrative:
-- At the time of this inspection the Animal Care regional offices located in Ft. Collins, CO and Raleigh, NC had not
received an itinerary from the licensee prior to overnight travel. The lack of a required itinerary was also noted on

contain complete and accurate information concerning the whereabouts of all animals intended for exhibition at any
location other than the approved site.

desc: HOUSING FACILITIES, GENERAL.
narrative:
-- The inside of the 48ft travel trailer that housed 26 dogs and 2 people was filthy. The ammonia odor upon entering
the trailer was very strong. There was an excessive accumulation of hair and other debris surrounding all of the
kennels. The kennels themselves appeared not to have been thoroughly cleaned and sanitized in some time.
Inadequate cleaning of animal housing can increase the disease risks for those animals. Kennels and surrounding
housing must be cleaned and sanitized and contaminated material must be replaced often enough to prevent
accumulation of excreta, reduce disease hazards, and prevent odors and pests.
To be corrected by: 10/6/16.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representative.
Additional Inspectors
Digesualdo Cynthia, Veterinary Medical Officer

leased, borrowed, loaned, or under some similar arrangement, the name of the person who owns such animal;
(ii) The name, identification number or identifying characteristics, species (common or scientific name), sex and age
of each animal; and
(iii) The names, dates, and locations (with addresses) where the animals will travel, be housed, and be exhibited,
including all anticipated dates and locations (with addresses) for any stops and layovers that allow or require
removal of the animals from the transport enclosures. Unanticipated delays of such length shall be reported to the
AC Regional Director the next APHIS business day. APHIS Regional offices are available each weekday, except on
Federal holidays, from 8 a.m. to 5 p.m.

desc: ACCESS AND INSPECTION OF RECORDS AND PROPERTY; SUBMISSION OF ITINERARIES.
narrative:
As a Class C exhibitor with no reported primary site, submitting an itinerary for the traveling animals is crucial to
ensuring that the animals are maintained in accordance with the Animal Welfare Act. There has been one
incomplete itinerary submitted to the inspector in September 2016, but not to the the Regional Director or
ACWest@aphis.usda.gov in 2015, 2016 or 2017. Complete and accurate itineraries must be submitted to the
Regional Director with the required information no fewer than 2 days in advance of any travel or move in order to
inspect the licensee.
Monday, June 19th, Inspector called the 760 number on the paperwork and left a voicemail asking for
itinerary/location in order to conduct inspection, with no response in 4 days. Inspector drove by the mailing address
and confirmed that the mailing address is a UPS store on Thursday, June 22nd, 2017. Internet research revealed
that FIDO 500 were an advertised exhibitor for the Silver Dollar Fair on May 25-29, 2017 and the fair website
detailed the FIDO 500 shows several times a day May 25-29th, 2017.

desc: ACCESS AND INSPECTION OF RECORDS AND PROPERTY; SUBMISSION OF ITINERARIES.
narrative:
No itinerary was submitted by the Exhibitor for this venue.
Itineraries are necessary to allow for the inspection of traveling exhibitors to confirm compliance with the Animal
Welfare Act, notably regarding the animal care and welfare while traveling.
Submission of itineraries as detailed in this regulation must be submitted for any overnight travel of regulated
species.

desc: PRIMARY ENCLOSURES.
narrative:
A number of the portable kennels used to house the dogs within the travel trailer were soiled. The fronts of multiple
cages were rusty. One cage was damaged near the top, with portions of the plastic missing.
Rust present on the doors prevents proper sanitation. Housing the dogs in enclosures in these conditions can cause
spread of disease.
A system of cleaning and maintenance must be in place to keep the primary enclosures of dogs clean and in good
repair.

desc: Consignments to carriers and intermediate handlers.
narrative:
There were three dogs that had arrived at the cargo office on British Airways Flight #285 from Heathrow Airport. Each
crate had a sticker on top with consignor and consignee information, but it did not include the time and date that the dogs
were last offered food and water. Dogs were on waybill #s 125-9476-2032 and 125-946-2253.
When accepting dogs for transport the airline must ensure that the consignor's certification regarding feeding and
watering is complete, so that the information is available to those handling the animals during transit. Failure to provide
the required information could result in handling that would be detrimental to the well-being of the animals.

desc: Consignments to carriers and intermediate handlers.
narrative:
There were three dogs that had arrived at the cargo office on British Airways Flight #285 from Heathrow Airport. Each
crate had a sticker on top with consignor and consignee information, but it did not include the consignor's signature and
time and date of signature. Dogs were on waybill #s 125-9476-2032 and 125-946-2253.
The consignor's certification should be signed with the time and date so as to clearly indicate the consignor's instructions
as to when the animals were last fed and watered, and what the consignor's instructions are for feeding and watering
during transit. Failure to provide this signed and dated certification by the consignor could put the well-being of the
animals at risk.

desc: Food and water requirements.
narrative:
There were three dogs that had arrived at the cargo office on British Airways Flight #285 from Heathrow Airport. Dogs
were on waybill #s 125-9476-2032 and 125-946-2253. The two smaller crates only had one food / water receptacle in
each enclosure.
Food and water receptacles should be attached inside the enclosure so that the dogs can be offered both food and water
during transit. When accepting dogs for transport, the airline should ensure that there are both food and water receptacles
in the enclosure. Failure to to do could be detrimental to the well-being of the animals, as it makes it difficult to offer food
and water per the consignor's instructions.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the cargo office personnel.
End Section

desc: Access and inspection of records and property; submission of itineraries.
narrative:
The licensee was observed to be exhibiting seven white-tailed deer fawns and two potbelly piglets at the Wayne County
Fair but no itinerary had been submitted to APHIS officials.
Traveling exhibitors must submit an itinerary to APHIS no fewer than 2 days in advance of any travel and shall contain
complete and accurate information concerning the whereabouts of any animal intended for exhibition at any location other
than the person's approved site. Failure to do so impedes APHIS officials ability to perform unannounced inspections of
traveling exhibits.
Correct by submitting an itinerary to APHIS no fewer than 2 days in advance of any future traveling exhibits of regulated
species.
Correct by: August 12, 2021
This inspection took place at the Wayne County Fair in Honesdale, PA.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee and his wife.
End Section

desc: HOUSING FACILITIES, GENERAL.
narrative:
Two male baboons are housed in a chain link outdoor enclosure with an attached sheltered enclosure. They have
destroyed a plank perch in the enclosure leaving 5 loose boards (possibly with nails) on the ground. A small metal
chain which held a round toy swing from the chain link ceiling is hanging loosely from the toy posing a potential
hanging hazard. All structures within non-human primate housing must be designed and constructed so that they
are structurally sound and kept in good repair to prevent potential injury of the animals. These broken structures
need to be repaired or replaced. To be corrected by 5-1-15.
Licensee was not present as both units are in travel status.
Inspection conducted of animals left at farm.
Exit briefing conducted with facility representative.

desc: RECORDS: DEALERS AND EXHIBITORS.
narrative:
Several animals have been born at the home site and are now in travel status with this unit. The acquisition records
for the births of the zebu, zebra, water buffalo, Scottish Hylander, and camel are not recorded. All acquisition
records need to be kept up to date.

desc: CLEANING, SANITIZATION, HOUSEKEEPING, AND PEST CONTROL.
narrative:
- A trail of rodent droppings was observed on the middle horizontal rail in the indoor portion of the enclosures in the
non-human primate building. This rail is clearly being used as a travel area for rodents to move from cage to cage.
These droppings are also on the resting surfaces for the chimpanzees and the Hamadryas Baboon, and were noted
among and adjacent to feed and water. Rodents carry diseases and may cause illness to the enclosed animals.
They can also contaminate food, water and living areas. Two rodent traps were located in the corners of the room,
but it is unclear if they had been properly prepared and monitored. The licensee must have an adequate program to
control pests in this building and must ensure proper pest control throughout the facility.
Correct by: Immediately

desc: Access and inspection of records and property; submission of itineraries.
narrative:
***There was no itinerary submitted for the travel that was conducted in November of 2023. Exhibitors exhibiting animals
at any location other than their approved site that includes an overnight stay are required to submit an itinerary no fewer
than 2 days in advance of any travel. The itinerary shall contain complete and accurate information concerning the
whereabouts of any animal intended for exhibition at any location other than the person’s approved site. To be corrected
prior to any future travel.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the Licensee.
Additional Inspectors:
Jeffrey Shepherd, SUPERVISORY ANIMAL CARE SPECIALISTEnd Section

desc: FACILITIES, GENERAL.
narrative:
When animals in traveling exhibits are taken off the transport enclosures, they need to be contained in enclosures
which protect the animals from injury and contain the animals. During this travel inspection, the goats were found
individually tied by a dog leash and collar to a 2 foot ground stake. The 5 baby goats are loose in the area. The
easy attack of a loose dog last week injuring two of the goats shows this "set up" is not safe for the animals. Being
tethered does not protect them from predators and does not keep the public out unless supervised. It could also
lead to entanglement as they run around the stake, or lead to their escape if the tether slips over the top of the
stake.
To be corrected by 4-3-15.

desc: FACILITIES, GENERAL.
narrative:
** When the animals in traveling exhibits are taken out of the transport enclosures, they need to be contained in
enclosures which protect the animals from injury and contain the animals. During this travel inspection, two male
goats were found individually tied by a dog leash and collar to a portable enclosure containing six goats. There is no
primary or secondary containment to protect them from unwanted animals or public. The easy attack of a loose dog
less than a year ago injuring two of the goats shows this "set up" is not safe for the animals. Being tethered does
not protect them from predators and does not keep the public out unless supervised. It could also lead to
entanglement or the inability to escape any potential dangers.
** The camel that was tied up with a lead rope to the trailer during its down time between shows was reluctant to
cush on the gravel substrate that was under him. It was explained to the manager that if the camel was provided the
proper materials or substrate appropriate for the camel to cush, it would probably do so. About 20 minutes later the
camel willingly cushed on its on without coercion. The facility must be constructed of such material as appropriate
for the animals involved.

of each animal; and
(iii) The names, dates, and locations (with addresses) where the animals will travel, be housed, and be exhibited,
including all anticipated dates and locations (with addresses) for any stops and layovers that allow or require
removal
of the animals from the transport enclosures. Unanticipated delays of such length shall be reported to the AC
